executive_summary: Candy producers have struggled to maintain consistent growth, contending with shifting consumer preferences, heightened competition and volatile economic conditions. Since candy provides little nutritional value, it is considered a discretionary good. When economic conditions are poor or uncertain, consumers reduce candy purchases. At the height of the pandemic, candy sales nearly stalled before booming in the following year. Still, producers were unable to maintain the growth, as import competition intensified with a strengthening US dollar. As a result, revenue increased at a CAGR of 1.4% to $12.9 billion through 2023, including a 2.6% decline in 2023 alone.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Growing Health Awareness Drives Innovation but Slows Revenue Growth
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Consumers are increasingly leery of products with high concentrations of sugar, which are linked to a slew of health issues. The trend drives consumers away from candy products but also forces producers to create new sugar-free and low-calorie options. Sugar-free candies represent a fluctuating but growing niche and a good entry point for new producers looking to find footing.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Competition Heats Up On All Sides
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: - Candy producers compete with other candy producers, imports and substitute products like chocolate, ice cream and sweet snacks. - A strengthening US dollar resulted in imported candy brands being relatively less expensive, siphoning sales from domestic producers. - Shifting consumer preferences are difficult to predict, so the largest companies produce substitute products to pivot with market demands.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Costs Rise, Pinching Already Slim Margins
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The price of sugar, a key input in candy production, rose significantly amid supply chain disruptions and detrimental growing conditions.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Excessive candy consumption is strongly linked to the development of diabetes among other serious health conditions. According to the Centers for Disease Control & Prevention (CDC), the number of Americans with diabetes grows yearly. An increasingly health-conscious public will drive producers to create healthier products, presenting new entrants with a potential foothold in the market. Brands unable or unwilling to cater to shifting consumer preferences will experience varying levels of setback depending on brand loyalty.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Fierce Competition Will Hinder Greater Revenue Growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: New producers will continue emerging, driving up internal competition and potentially saturating the market. Specializing in seasonal, sugar-free or novelty products will provide a route to growth for some. Chocolate will continue representing a major external source, siphoning customers away from candy producers. However, a weakening dollar will result in easing imports and a rise in exports.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Prices Are Slated to Rise, Signaling Bad News for Returns
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The price of sugar will continue rising but at a slightly slower pace than through 2023.

industry_definition: The Candy Production industry produces confectionery, such as hard candies, gum, candied fruits, fudge, halvah, marshmallows and toffee, as well as breakfast bars. Finished goods are distributed to confectionery and grocery wholesalers and retailers, which then sell the candy to households and other consumers. The industry does not produce chocolates, chocolate confectionery, ice cream or frozen yogurt.
key_trends: Competition is fierce and comes in many forms, including other candy brands, imports and substitute products, like chocolate and ice cream. Yet, new candy producers continue popping up.
Growing detrimental conditions and supply issues drove sugar prices up. Producers struggled to pass costs on to consumers, cutting into returns.
Candy producers must adhere to a slew of regulations since they produce and sell food items. These regulations are overseen by several federal agencies.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Retailers include businesses like grocery stores, drug stores and convenience stores, which sell candy directly to consumers. Grocery stores and convenience stores, in particular, represent key markets due to high rates of foot traffic and the ability to sell an array of products. Smaller candy producers can avoid wholesale costs by selling directly to retailers.

Confectionary wholesalers purchase products from candy producers and sell them to downstream retail markets. Using a wholesaler enables a company to reach a broader customer base, possibly expanding to more regions. Wholesaling can be cost prohibitive, especially for smaller or emerging candy producers. The market remains stable, as large companies, like Hershey, rely on wholesalers to reach their large customer base.

Exports represent domestically produced products sold to international markets. Breaking into the international market is difficult and costly, so exports represent a relatively small revenue share. Trade disruptions drove up the price of exports, deterring international consumers. The value of the US dollar also increased, making domestically produced goods relatively more expensive in overseas markets.

products_and_services.product_description: Chewy candies include bars made of various confectioneries like peanut butter or toffee, along with granola and breakfast bars. The segment is wildly popular, as many of its products, like granola bars, satisfy health-conscious and sweet-tooth driven customers. Consumers across age demographics enjoy chewy candies, shielding the segment from preference shifts.

Gum is a rubbery candy that is chewed but not swallowed, while mints are small, hard candies that release flavor over time. Traditionally, gum and mints were marketed as breath-freshening products, but producers now offer gum and mints in various flavors. Gum and mints are popular with most age groups, but health perceptions pertaining to the products fluctuates, resulting in varying sale performance.

Specialty candies include seasonal, holiday and limited-release varieties, along with novelty candies. The segment increased substantially as specialty candies became a popular gifting option. It can be difficult to break into the segment, as many seasonal candies enjoy brand loyalty and national, or international, distribution.

Sugar-free candies use sugar substitutes to create a sweet taste, significantly reducing the use of sugar or avoiding it entirely. A rise in health consciousness bred the sugar-free segment, and consumers' continued interest in such options means brands continue to try new variants. The segment declined but represents a key entry point for new and small candy producers looking for a niche.

Other candies include hard candies, licorice, caramel and taffy, among others. Candies in this segment enjoy less broad appeal, with the largest market being older demographics who tend to spend less on confectionary goods. These candies are also highly associated with dental issues, deterring many parents from purchasing them for children.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: This industry does not produce chocolate confectionery, which is instead manufactured by the Chocolate Production industry (31135). Therefore, chocolate represents a substitute product and often displaces demand for this industry's products. Demand from chocolate production is expected to decline in 2023.

Per capita disposable income measures an individual's ability to purchase goods or services. As income rises, consumers are more likely to purchase nonessential goods, such as candy. Though health concerns have driven many consumers away from candy, per capita disposable income is expected to rise in 2023.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Per Capita Sugar and Sweetener Consumption
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Consumers have become more health-conscious and have moved away from traditionally sugar-rich foods. Because most candy is heavy in sugar, any decline in sugar consumption translates to lower demand for industry products. Per capita sugar and sweetener consumption is expected to decrease in 2023.

Sugar is the key ingredient in most candies, so its prices impact the industry. Candy producers have largely been able to pass along cost increases downstream via higher selling prices, causing revenue to rise when sugar prices rise. Conversely, selling prices and revenue fall when sugar prices decline. The price of sugar is expected to rise in 2023.

The value of the US dollar compared with other currencies, as measured by the trade-weighted index (TWI), affects the volume of exports. A declining TWI reflects a depreciating dollar, making US goods less expensive for international markets and boosting export revenue. The TWI is expected to rise in 2023.

international_trade_points.trade_description: Imports account for about one-quarter of domestic demand. The pandemic and subsequent supply chain issues initially resulted in declining imports, but the trend swiftly reversed. Certain countries are renowned for specific candy varieties and the appeal can persist through economic uncertainty.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Imports Grow as the Dollar Strengthens
international_trade_points.trade_description: The value of the US dollar increased, making imported candy brands relatively more affordable for domestic consumers. Imports from Mexico, Germany and Turkey increased, while imports from Canada contracted.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Volatile Economic Conditions Result in Fluctuating Export Values
international_trade_points.trade_description: Exports account for a relatively small, declining share of revenue. The value of exports tanked at the height of the pandemic, as trade disruptions prevailed and international consumers cut spending. Exports spiked as trade disruptions eased but too little to make up for pandemic losses.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Key International Markets Show Some Signs of Change
international_trade_points.trade_description: Canada remains the largest importer of US candy due to its proximity and favorable trade agreements. Mexico is a key importer of US candy but declined as a share of exports, contributing to overall losses. The Netherlands and the United Kingdom increased domestic imports, but a strengthening US dollar resulted in weakening sales in developing nations.

business_locations.location_description: The West is home to more candy producers than any other region in the country. Much of this concentration is based in California, which has more candy producers than New England and the Plains regions combined. No major players are headquartered in the West but many medium-sized businesses operate in the area, including Jelly Belly.

The Mid-Atlantic contains the second-highest concentration of candy producers, with the Great Lakes close behind. Pennsylvania is the third most concentrated state and is home to the Hershey Company, a major player.
The Great Lakes region is close to many upstream suppliers of key inputs like sugar, making it a prime area.

The Southeast has the highest concentration of the US population but has considerably fewer candy producers. The number of production companies in the region is rising, with major player Marcs Inc. headquartered in Virginia. The Southeast is ripe for candy production, as it is home to several large cities, like Atlanta and Miami, and a massive customer base.

regulations_points.regulation_title: The Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (FD&C Act)
regulations_points.regulation_description: Congress first passed the FD&C Act in 1938, replacing the Pure Food and Drug Act of 1906. The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) oversees the FD&C Act. It has been amended many times, but the set of laws broadly pertains to the safety of food, along with drugs, medical devices and cosmetics. The Act is large in scope, containing things like the definition of chewing gum as a food and determining the potential harm of additives.

regulations_points.regulation_title: THE FAIR PACKAGING AND LABELING ACT (FPLA)
regulations_points.regulation_description: The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) and the FDA oversee the FPLA. Congress passed the FPLA in 1966 to ensure consumers were properly informed of what foods they were buying and what they contained. The Act specifically requires all food product labels to include the name of the product, where it was produced, packaged and, if relevant, distributed and its net quantity. All candy producers must follow these regulations.

Several statutes and regulations overseen by the EPA are relevant to candy production. Acts, including the Clean Water Act, Clean Air Act, Pollution Prevention Act and the Resources and Conservation and Recovery Act, affect candy producers in some way. For instance, most candy production facilities discharge wastewater and must adhere to these policies to complete such tasks.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Candy production is becoming increasingly reliant on automated technologies and less reliant on a physical workforce.

barriers_points.barrier_title: Smaller producers rely on physical workforce
barriers_points.barrier_description: Still, smaller and nascent producers rely on physical workers in place of pricier machinery.

basis_points.basis_description: Consumers have many candy options to choose from and brand loyalty runs rampant. New producers must find a niche and excel in it.
Chocolate sales are excluded from revenue, making them a substantial source of competition. Some chose to produce both candy and chocolate products, allowing them to shift with consumer preferences.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Giant international candy producers, like Mars Inc. and Hershey Co., account for more than one-quarter of all candy revenue.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Large companies operate in related industries
concentration_points.concentration_description: These companies operate in several other related industries, like chocolate production, allowing them to pivot with consumer sentiment.
Major companies also have international appeal, enabling them to cater to broader markets.
Candy producers mainly come in two sizes, very big or fairly small.
An influx of small, local producers has driven down market share concentration, though some end up acquired by larger producers.

concentration_points.concentration_title: High operating costs for small producers
concentration_points.concentration_description: Small producers experience much higher operating costs, making thriving difficult.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Poor Growing Conditions and Supply Chain Difficulties Raise Purchase Costs
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Detrimental growing conditions, at home and abroad, resulted in the price of sugar increasing substantially. Sugar distribution, among other key inputs, was disrupted by the Russian invasion of Ukraine, which resulted in logistical transportation and trade issues.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Candy production is becoming increasingly reliant on automated technologies
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Candy production is becoming increasingly reliant on automated technologies and less reliant on a physical workforce. Still, smaller and nascent producers rely on physical workers in place of pricier machinery.

volatility_points.volatility_title: CANDY IS UNESSENTIAL, PASSED OVER WHEN MONEY IS TIGHT
volatility_points.volatility_description: Candy is typically considered a discretionary purchase, as it contains little meaningful nutritionary value.

Imported candy brands capture about one-quarter of all domestic demand. When the value of imports rises swiftly, sales of domestic brands tend to waver. The value of the US dollar increased, making imports relatively more affordable for domestic consumers, boosting import sales.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Chocolate Products are a Formidable Foe
volatility_points.volatility_description: Chocolate candy products are created and sold by producers in different industries, so chocolate is a major source of competition. Chocolate is generally more expensive than other candy products, so when economic conditions are positive, many opt for chocolate.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The rate of new patent technologies entering the industry is low, which limits the potential for innovations. A low rate does not mean that innovations cannot occur, just that the likelihood of some innovation materializing as a threat is lower. However, the concentration of technologies is high in this industry. This suggests that industry operators have exposure to potentially unforeseen areas of innovation.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Major market segments for industry operators are relatively diversified
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Major market segments for industry operators are relatively diversified. The spread of market segments suggests that there are limited entry points other than those already served my incumbent operators.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in a niche or do you produce a diversified range of products?
FAQs.answer: Large companies (i.e. Hershey's, Mars and Nestle) have a broad portfolio of household known products.

FAQs.question: Have exports offered an opportunity for your company?
FAQs.answer: Exports generate a small but important portion of industry revenue. An appreciating dollar causes domestic goods to be relatively more expensive in foreign markets, hurting exports.

FAQs.question: Has your company located near key downstream distributors to reduce shipping costs?
FAQs.answer: Many operators sell their products to distributors located closely to business operations in order to cut costs.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: Sugar is the primary input into nonchocolate candies. A rise in the price of sugar affects operators differently.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs through automation over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Increased automation has limited employment growth in recent years.

FAQs.question: How is your company leveraging new technology, such as RFID tags?
FAQs.answer: Tracking sales enables companies to optimize production levels to reduce waste.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all health and safety requirements are met?
FAQs.answer: Keeping a minimum level of health and safety is of paramount importance to industry operators. If health and safety standards are not met, a company could potentially face fines.

FAQs.question: Have any regulatory expenses significantly impacted profitability recently?
FAQs.answer: The FDA closely monitors the production of goods, such as candy. Companies must abide by FDA regulations and procedures related to the COVID-19 pandemic.

FAQs.question: How has input price volatility affected profit over the past 12 months?
FAQs.answer: Volatility in the price of sugar has had a significant effect on profit year over year, exacerbated by the COVID-19 pandemic.

FAQs.question: What percentage of your customers renew their contracts?
FAQs.answer: Brand loyalty is important in confectionery products. Consumers will continue to purchase their brand of choice despite price hikes.

FAQs.question: How flexible is your production line? How do you prop up demand during the off-season?
FAQs.answer: Successful companies have the ability to anticipate and respond to changes in consumer preferences in a timely manner, given the seasonal nature of confectionery demand.

FAQs.question: How do your products stand out? Have you updated your packaging recently?
FAQs.answer: As candy products are typically homogeneous, successful companies are able to differentiate their products to stand out from competition, maintain market share and drive revenue growth.

FAQs.question: How strong are your upstream relationships? Do you have any locked-in agreements with suppliers that work to your advantage?
FAQs.answer: Companies that have reliable contracts with key raw material suppliers can reduce supply volatility as they have guaranteed supplies at fixed prices; this minimizes costs and aids production and inventory planning.

FAQs.question: Can you brand your products in opposition to chocolate? How heavily are your customers switching to chocolate over your candy?
FAQs.answer: Chocolate is a substitute product and often displaces demand for this industry's products.

FAQs.question: What sugar alternatives are you experimenting with for new products? How heavily will the low-sugar trend impact your revenue?
FAQs.answer: Consumers are becoming more health-conscious and moving away from traditionally sugar-rich foods. Since most candy is sugar-heavy, a decline in per capita sugar and sweetener consumption could negatively impact revenue.
